The Texas photo voter ID law has been in effect for two years. Voter turnout was up across all demographic groups, including  blacks and Hispanics, in last fall's election.  Poll workers reported the election went smoothly with no unusual problems. Early voting turnout so far has been up in this fall's mid-term election with no more than the usual number of problems. Most people cast provisional ballots because they left their IDs at home. They don't show back up with their IDs as required because by then they know who won the election.  People persist in fantasizing that photo voter ID laws prevent hundreds of thousands of people from voting even though their fantasy conflicts with actual voter turnout.

This is a great idea. A possible problem is that there are legitimate reasons for having to vote with a provisional ballot - for example, voters who attempt to vote somewhere outside their jurisdiction of residence. If it can be shown that these cases are much less common than failure to have the required photo ID, then it can work.

Another problem is that it is likely that a significant number of voters without photo ID will not even show up to vote because they know they would be turned away.

One clear way to prove these laws disenfranchise is for every voter denied the right to vote to fill out a provisional ballot. Though limited, they do allow the person to cast a vote, but in states like Texas, the voter must return within a specific, and very short amount of time to prove their eligibility to vote in that state. It only matters that they come back with the ID, if they have or can get one to ensure their chosen candidate wins. But what the provisional ballot does for those who don't have the proper ID, it provides proof of disenfranchisement. If during the election a large number of minority voters cannot casta regular ballot but can cast a provisional ballot, they can then prove to SCOTUS that the new laws in Texas do and have suppressed the minority vote and that the election is in fact a fraud! This must be done I. Every state that has enacted any voter restrictions. What would SCOTUS say if during this cycle, which tends to have a much lower turnout than presidential elections, 2 million voters nationwide had to submit a provisional ballot because the new laws prevented them from voting? What if it were five or ten million? Would SCOTUS order those votes counted? How would each state be held accountable? What would the results be if this many we denied the right to vote and decided to sue the states in federal court? What would the punitive damages be? How could one calculate the levels of damage caused to each person?

Proposing over-the-counter birth control (besides easy stuff like condoms) is like suggesting that people remove their own limbs like in the movie "127 Hours".

In order to use birth control successfully and safely, women need advice from a medical professional, just as I get advice on my non-contraceptive health care.

Saying "let's make this widely available and take medical professionals out of the equation" is dooming women to all sorts of complications. It's facetious. It treats every female issue like a "lingerie party" -- something nonserious.

Reject any politician who treats birth control as something less deserving of medical care (and medical insurance) than erectile dysfunction.

There haven't been "pre-human conditions" in the United States for at least 10,000 years, and perhaps much, much longer, depending on which archaeologist you talk to.

The problem with European colonization isn't the people per se, but the number of keystone species that were wiped out in the process--the buffalo who help the prairie regenerate, the beavers who changed the water system throughout the southwest, the wolves who keep river banks from being denuded by hunting large grazing animals.

At this point, if we just "leave nature alone" in the American, and don't restock these species, we will be reducing biodiversity and impoverishing our natural heritage.
How about reclaiming blighted urban areas? Not a simple answer, but preferable to developing wild places.
How about the midwest?

Protecting wilderness does not mean restoring it to pre human conditions.

We have lost almost 90% of the wilderness that was here before the European invasion. The eastern US was forested from the Atlantic to the Mississippi, and by the time of TR it was mostly gone. So, most of what we have left is in the west. That includes our deserts, mountains, and seashores. We have saved 9% of the redwoods after the lumber industry to the rest, and about 10% of the old growth forest. Today the desert is being industrialized much as predicted by Edward Abbey in his book "Desert Solitaire." What we need to do is let our wilderness alone, and it will evolve as it has been doing for millennia. We can clean up the streams and lakes, the pollution left by industries like logging, mining, and other extraction activities. We need to clean up the air, it is still toxic, particularly to children.

We just saw protests in Los Angeles and cities east along the San Gabriel Mountains over Obama's declaration of them as National Wilderness, preventing the developers from encroaching any further than they have. The biggest threats to wilderness here, are the developers, cities that allow building right up to the boundaries, energy industries like wind and solar power, and developers, who can never get enough cheap land to build on.

Some management is needed, such as getting rid of the invasive species in the Everglades, but in general, just let wilderness be wilderness.

Our priority (since the space race) seems to have been to release the rich from the burdens of taxation and regulation. Along the way we trimmed government funding for NASA, education, highways, etc., and allowed our infrastructure to crumble.

Now that the rich (as Warren Buffett observes) pay lower tax rates than their secretaries, the rich have fortunes to burn on a few minutes of space flight.

A country that favors thrill rides for the rich over education for its children has its priorities upside down.

This is awful. I hope we all take a breather here and think about our priorities.

I hope this tragedy - the unnecessary death of a fellow human - serves as a wake-up call that there are far more enriching, empowering endeavors we can pursue than spending a few minutes in space. Space tourism is not bold or trailblazing; it's shallow. It's not pushing the human race forward or solving our problems here on Earth. At best, it gives a tiny fraction of our population a selfie opportunity and emits massive amounts of pollutants into our atmosphere.

Humans do more incredible things with less waste. We are also innately social beings and so our best work comes when shared widely. As a suggestion, how about you take a sketchpad and imagine how some part of the human experience could be radically better. Post the idea on a website and everyone who sees it can be inspired. We see this empowerment on places like Kickstarter for physical goods, and Medium for ideas and social commentary, and Flickr for photography. That's what actual progress looks like.

What was the time of that announcement? I was watching coverage on cable news in the early-mid afternoon Eastern time, and during the earlier part I saw rescue crews had not yet reached the wreckage and no one knew that only one pilot had survived.

We should also keep in mind that hundreds, literally hundreds, of people were killed in the development of aviation. Even one of the Wright brothers was killed flying one of their planes. As commercial air travel developed, I would estimate there were, at least, several thousand deaths related to improving aircraft design, pilot training and skills and the air traffic control system.

Working on a documentary once, I had the occasion to go through old newsreels from the 1940s, '50s and '60s at the National Archives in College Park, Maryland. In the course of one year's time, there would normally be one, two or three major airline crashes killing dozens, if not more than one hundred, in each crash. The Lockheed Electra, a turbo-prop commercial aircraft, regularly broke apart when encountering thunderstorms. The record of aviation was accepted by most of the public as part of the price of having commercial aviation, but now such deaths would be consider appalling. In the fields of aviation and space flight, there is little progress made without great sacrifice.

Rocket flight is dangerous.  The reason is that the propulsive power is closer to the failure point of its containment vessel than with standard jet propulsion.  In addition, the propellant may be in close physical proximity to the burn front as is the case with solid fuels, in which the burn front forms the combustion chamber.  This is extremely risky  propulsion for humans to dare to use, as has been proved tragically by our astronaut deaths.  Rockets are a deadly risk.
Flying obscenely rich people to the moon for a vacation is a worthy cause? There are so many real problems in the world needing solutions, needing the cash and brains wasted here.

Years ago, I have the opportunity to cover America's space program for NPR and before that for a local television station (we did special reports and, on some occasions, 24/7 newsbreaks). I always thought then that the real opportunity in space would come when someone besides highly trained jet test pilots got the chance to go into space. NASA followed this same thinking for a time when they decided to send teachers into space and, at one point, asked network television news anchors if they wanted to take a ride (they all signed up for possible flights, except Peter Jennings, who was then anchor for ABC News). (Two U.S. senators went up on the SpaceShuttle.)

NASA was looking for people who could go up and bring the wonder and excitement of space travel back down to earth. The test pilots were wonderful people, but they mainly had the engineering mentality, which was to put their complete concentration on the equipment, how to manage and run it. There are very few engineer/poets. It seems like a contradiction in terms, in fact.

Civilians going up to near space might seem like a silly stunt, as it does to many of the people commenting here, apparently, but it is part of the process of taking space travel out of the realm of scientists and engineers and making it more of a normal event. We might never get to the point where people fly to the moon for a month's vacation, but it is a possibility and one worthy of pursuing, even at this high cost.
